SHORTPROSE.P:
QV came from the Hanoverian line of the English monarchy and learned English as a second language to German from the age of three. She occupied an anomalous role as the white female ruler of a vast British empire which eventually allowed her, as its Empress, to count one quarter of humanity as her subjects. The peculiarity of her role, along with the portliness emphasized by her short stature, is evoked in Anna Leonowens's tongue-in-cheek report 140-5 25-7 of a Siamese ambassador's comment that QV must be of pure descent from a race of goodly and warlike kings and rulers of the earth, in that her eyes, complexion, and above all her bearing, are those of a beautiful and majestic white elephant. 145
Leonowens details the elaborate and costly ceremonials surrounding the white elephant. Her sense of their ridiculousness connects to the notion, derived from Siamese culture, of white elephants as a burdensome possession,
which suggests that the ambassador's remark may have had an anti-imperial twist.

Although she was obviously an aristocrat, QV's sensibilities in many respects allied her with the middle classes. She defined herself against the excesses of the Regency, and her public performance of domesticity and wifely devotion, as well as many of her tastes and opinions, helped to legitimise bourgeois values in the period that was named after her.
QV was a devout Anglican, as befitted the head of the Church of England. (When in Scotland, however, she attended the local Presbyterian, that is Church of Scotland, parish church.)

QV's 1837-1901 reign was the longest of any British monarch. By taking a dedicated and active role in the rule of her country—despite her assertion that I never interfere in politics 43 —she helped Britain survive times of intense political turmoil and served as an example of a strong female public leader during a time when dominant ideologies of gender represented women as queens within the private domestic sphere. Despite being associated early in her reign more with the Whigs and reform measures than with the more conservative Tories, she was not particularly progressive. xviii Although her dislike of radicalism may have been in part owing to the early guidance in government she received from Lord Melbourne, she also exhibited a deep-rooted faith in convention and tradition.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Alexandrina Victoria, fifth in line to the throne and the future Queen of England, was born at Kensington Palace.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her birth was witnessed and attested, as dictated by traditional royal custom. 1

Interestingly, although Victoria later opposed female midwives and doctors, she was delivered by a German midwife, Fräulein Siebold. Her parents, the Duke and Duchess of Kent, were living in Germany until the last month of the pregnancy. At this time the Duke decided that the child should be born in England, as she was close enough to the succession to be of concern to the government and royal family. 1 Despite the risk to his wife's health and their lack of money, they journeyed towards English soil. Victoria was born a few days after their arrival. 23-4 21
QV's future husband, Prince Albert, was delivered by the same midwife as Victoria, just over three months later. 22

QV's mother was Victoire of Leiningen, Princess of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfield, Duchess of Kent, who came from a strong line of German monarchy. 1 16, 19 253 Victoire was a thirty-year-old widow, with two children by her late German husband, Prince Emich Charles of Leiningen, when she married Edward Augustus, QV's father. After her second marriage, she was referred to in England as Victoria, Duchess of Kent. The marriage was purely an economic one. 16 xiii

According to biographer Elizabeth Longford, when people remarked that [Victoria] resembled her royal father she would claim with a tightening of the lips to have inherited more from my dear Mother. 19

QV's father, Edward Augustus, Duke of Kent, was a son of domestic and high-minded parents, George III and Queen Charlotte, but since their day the House of Hanover had become renowned for debauchery and imprudence. Edward Augustus grew up to be an army officer, then ex-officer exiled in relative poverty in Brussels for many years. Before marrying, he lived with a French woman, Julie, Madame de St Laurent, for twenty-seven years. 15-16

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Edward, Duke of Kent, died of pneumonia less than eight months after the birth of his daughter Alexandrina Victoria, future queen of England.

SHORTPROSE.P: Although QV was the only child of Edward Augustus and Victoire, she had two older siblings from her mother's first marriage, her half-brother Charles and her half-sister Feodore, who was twelve years her elder and married when Victoria was nine. 29 16
Princess Victoria had many cousins, the most significant of whom was Albert, her future husband. 52

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The Duke and Duchess of Kent's daughter was christened Alexandrina Victoria, after heated arguments during the ceremony.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Prince Regent vehmently objected to the original names chosen by the Duke: Georgina Charlotte Augusta Alexandrina Victoria, a name designed to honour both his parents. The final choice was unpopular in England because both names were foreign. The arguments over naming foreshadowed the constant political struggle which Drina faced while growing up as a potential successor to the throne. 23-4
As an infant, the future queen was breast-fed, and vaccinated against smallpox. 19, 24

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After the Duke of Kent died, his impoverished wife and daughter (the Princess Alexandrina Victoria) were forced to move into Kensington Palace and live at the expense of Prince Leopold.

SHORTPROSE.P: QV remembered much of her childhood as sad and dull. The little girl quickly became known for her sociability and hot temper. 26-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A German woman, Louise Lehzen, was hired as governess to Princess Alexandrina Victoria.

SHORTPROSE.P: This appointment created anxiety within the family on account of the strong German influence which Lehzen would exercise. In fact, Victoria, whose mother spoke only German to her, did not even begin to speak English until the age of three; however, from that point she was allowed to speak German only during language lessons. 29-31 1-2
Lehzen established the tradition of reading history to Victoria while the young heiress dressed in her chambers. This practice continued even after Victoria became Queen. 30

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: By the age of seven, Princess Alexandrina Victoria was learning the classics, as well as history, scripture, and moral tales.

SHORTPROSE.P: These were taught her by her first formal teacher, the young and Evangelical Reverend George Davys. At eight, she began learning Latin. 31
Victoria was trained in music from an early age, and particularly enjoyed singing lessons with John Sale. Later, the famous tenor Luigi Lablache was employed to teach her. 31, 45

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alexandrina Victoria had begun reading her first novel, Sir Walter Scott's Bride of Lammermoor; she remained an avid reader of novels throughout her life.
While studying the history of the British monarchy, young Princess Alexandrina Victoria discovered her claim to the throne.

SHORTPROSE.P: Looking over the genealogical tables she realised her own position as successor, and is said to have burst into tears. Upon recovering, she uttered the famous phrase I will be good. 32

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alexandrina Victoria and her entourage embarked on a formal tour of the country, beginning with Wales and the Midlands.
Princess Alexandrina Victoria was confirmed an Anglican at the Chapel Royal, St James's, London.
Against her wishes, Princess Alexandrina Victoria was sent on another grand tour, this time of the North of England.

SHORTPROSE.P: Victoria was conscious of the fact that these travels angered the king, and were designed solely to promote her public image as successor. 47

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alexandrina Victoria suffered an acute attack of typhoid; she took a further three months to recover fully.

SHORTPROSE.P: This illness enabled the opposition to spread rumours about her weak health and suggest that she unsuitable for the crown. 50

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alexandrina Victoria became patron of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, along with her mother, the Duchess of Kent.
With the king close to death, Princess Alexandrina Victoria was pressed from all political sides to align herself with an advisor and party; she chose Lord Melbourne.

SHORTPROSE.P: She made her choice despite the protests and schemes of her mother and her confidant Sir John (later Lord) Conroy. 58-9

Conroy had been equerry to her father and then an important support to her mother in difficult political situations and the dominant political influence on the young Victoria. Her assertion of independence from him was an important step in her maturing. under Conroy

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg, Princess Alexandrina Victoria's cousin, visited England for the first time.

SHORTPROSE.P: She described him in her journal as full of goodness and sweetness, and very clever and intelligent. 52

Victoria had been informally matched to Albert from an early age, and knew from her uncle Prince Leopold that this young cousin, along with two others, was a future suitor. 31-3 51-2 Albert was a staunch Lutheran, and loved music, science, technology, and art. 52-3, 129 33

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alexandrina Victoria received the news that she was Queen, on the death of William IV of Britain.

SHORTPROSE.P: At about five o'clock in the morning, Lord Conyngham arrived at Kensington Palace, demanding to see the Queen; in a private interview, he informed the young and sleepy princess that she had acceded to the throne of England. At eighteen, she had just reached the age at which a regency was not required. Her journals of this time emphasize the alienated position into which she felt herself pushed, perpetually alone with important decisions to make. 60-4 23

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV opened Parliament, witnessed by many including Lady Morgan, who admired her composure and oral delivery.

SHORTPROSE.P: Morgan commented: The young Queen's aplomb was truly wonderful; her voice clear and sonorous—whoever taught the young girl to read, did every justice to the development of her vocal organ, and her small person seemed to dilate under the pressure of her conscious greatness; for the Queen of England is, at this moment, certainly the greatest sovereign in the world, because she is the chief of a free people—what charmed me most, however, was her inexpressibly girlish laugh. 2: 428

That month, Parliament awarded QV an annual Civil List Pension of £385,000 for the rest of her life; in addition, she received revenues from the Duchies of Cornwall and Lancaster.
73

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alexandrina Victoria was crowned Queen in Westminster Abbey.

SHORTPROSE.P: The day after her accession she had officially dropped her first name, and ordered it removed from all documentation.
By December she was already weary of life as a monarch, and close to a nervous breakdown. 71, 92-4

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg made a second visit to England to see his cousin QV.

SHORTPROSE.P: Victoria had written to her uncle less than three months before to tell him that any marriage should be postponed, and that the thought of matrimony held great repugnance 125 for her. Naturally, Albert felt little chance of success when he arrived, but after only four days Victoria, charmed by his handsome looks and intelligent manner, found her attitude changing and fell in love with him. 133 33

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV proposed marriage to Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg after spending a short time with him.

SHORTPROSE.P: The fact that she had to propose to him was the source of considerable public ridicule. The collision between the hierarchy of power which made Victoria queen and head of state, against the gender ideology and practices that should have made Albert king of his household, provided much fodder for jest in the press. 31ff

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV and Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg were married in the Chapel Royal, St James's Palace.

SHORTPROSE.P: Since Salic Law was not practised in England, QV ruled in her own right, and anyone who married her would be placed in the role of consort to the sovereign. Thus, the controversial issues of the Prince's status and income took some time to resolve before the marriage; after that, even the details of the wedding underwent debate. 31-6

There also arose the question of whether the ceremony was to be public or private. Lord Melbourne convinced QV, despite her hesitation, that a public ceremony was the only viable option, and she was duly married in public. Another conflict involved the honeymoon. QV disregarded Albert's wishes by shortening their stay at Windsor, saying: You forget, my dearest Love, that I am the Sovereign and that business can stop and wait for nothing. 140 He soon lamented his position as husband, not the master of the house, despite the fact that the relationship was otherwise happy. 148 139-40

There was much political turmoil amongst Members of Parliament on public notification of the marriage, owing to the prince's German heritage and Victoria's position of power combined with her gender and her youth. Albert was suspected of having foreign loyalties. 136-7 33 He certainly came to wield considerable political influence, acting as Victoria's secretary and drafting memoranda for her. 836

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Prince Albert was officially granted the title of Prince Consort.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Tories were instrumental in voting him only £30,000 a year, only about half the expected stipend for a Prince Consort. 136-7
QV had her first of nine children within a year of her marriage. Despite her prolific rate of reproduction, she had a tremendous dislike for the processes of pregnancy and childbirth.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: When QV was five months pregnant, Prince Albert was appointed Regent in the event of her death in childbirth.

CHRONPROSE.CHILDREN: After a twelve-hour labour, QV gave birth to her first child: Victoria Adelaide Mary Louise, Princess Royal.

SHORTPROSE.P: Albert had wanted an official announcement of QV's pregnancy, but Melbourne preferred the news to circulate informally. 151

Victoria was not close to her child during the first few months; she saw babies as froglike. 154 Years later, she admitted that while she did not dislike babies, . . . very young ones [were] rather disgusting. 228 A wet-nurse took care of the baby, who was commonly known as Vicky and affectionately called Pussy. 154 xvi
Victoria called childbirth the shadow-side of marriage 154 or die Schattenseite, a description which implies the secrecy and pain of pregnancy and labour.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV gave birth to her second child, the heir to the throne, Albert Edward, Prince of Wales.

SHORTPROSE.P: Commonly referred to as Bertie, he became in due course King Edward VII. Prince Albert purposely broke with the tradition of inviting the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Lord President of the Council for the birth. 168 xiv

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Prince Albert and QV had a major argument over the management of their children, and the position of Baroness Lehzen in the household.

SHORTPROSE.P: Lehzen left on 30 September 1842 without saying goodbye to the Queen. 162

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Princess Alice Mary Maud, QV's third child, was born.
At Windsor, QV gave birth to her fourth child, Prince Alfred Ernest Albert, Duke of Edinburgh and Duke of Coburg, commonly referred to as Affie.

SHORTPROSE.P: The newly-developed telegraph was used to announce his birth. 49

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV gave birth to Princess Helena Augusta Victoria, her fifth child, commonly known as Lenchen.
Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, QV's sixth child, who was commonly known as Loosy, was born.

SHORTPROSE.P: She became a sculptor, who exhibited three portrait works at the Royal Academy between 1868 and 1874.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV gave birth to Prince Arthur William Patrick Albert, Duke of Connaught, her seventh child.
QV gave birth to her eighth child, Prince Leopold George Duncan Albert, Duke of Albany; her use of chloroform during this birth popularized pain relief for women in labour.

SHORTPROSE.P: QV never glamourized birth and pregnancy, and was willing to undergo the controversial new pain relief to ease the process. She thought of birth as being like a cow or a dog at such moments; when our poor nature becomes so very animal and unecstatic. 105 Birth arrangements, in the Queen's opinion, were too horrid—and quite like an execution. Oh! if those selfish men—who are the cause of all one's misery, only knew what their poor slaves go through! What suffering—what humiliation to the feelings of a poor woman, above all a young one—especially with those nasty doctors. 115 With such sentiments, QV opted for chloroform.
Doctor John Snow administered the drug. The British Medical Journal was not convinced that Queen Victoria had in fact used chloroform and maintained that this was merely a rumour. 22

The obstetrical use of chloroform had been publicized by Dr James Young Simpson in 1847. 22 A fierce debate ensued in pamphlets and medical journals between proponents of the practice and religious authorities. The latter viewed labour pain as a divinely ordained consequence of Eve's transgression—which interdicted medical intervention. In addition, there were concerns even among medical men that the use of anaesthesia stimulated women and led to displays of sexual arousal. Victoria's sanction went a great way towards making the use of chloroform in childbirth respectable. 24, 27, 30

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV gave birth to Princess Beatrice Mary Victoria Feodora, commonly known as Baby.

SHORTPROSE.P: She used anaesthesia for this delivery as well. 835

As well as being busy with her many pregnancies and births, QV was a tireless and devoted monarch and mother, who orchestrated not only the affairs of her country, but also those of her ever-growing family. She arranged marriages for her children which fostered alliances between Britain and most other countries in Europe.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV's eldest daughter, Crown Princess Victoria, married Prince Frederick of Prussia.
QV's eldest daughter, Princess Victoria of Prussia, gave birth a year after her marriage to a son nicknamed Willie, who later became Kaiser Wilhelm II.
QV's daughter Crown Princess Alice married Prince Louis of Hesse-Darmstadt.
The Prince of Wales, and heir to the throne of Britain, Edward Albert, married Princess Alexandra of Denmark.
QV's daughter Crown Princess Helena married Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Augustenburg.
QV's daughter Crown Princess Louise married the Marquess of Lorne (heir to the dukedom of Argyll).

SHORTPROSE.P: The Prince of Wales was in this year seriously ill with typhoid. xvii

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV's son Crown Prince Alfred married Marie, Grand Duchess of Russia.
QV's son Crown Prince Arthur married Louise of Prussia.
QV's son Crown Prince Leopold married Helen of Waldeck.
QV's daughter Crown Princess Beatrice married Prince Henry of Battenburg.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Despite the geographical distances between QV and her married children, she maintained contact with them through her voluminous correspondence. She and her eldest daughter, Crown Princess Victoria, wrote especially regularly, often several times a week, over a span of forty years. 1-2 5
QV's correspondence with her eldest daughter is collected in six volumes, five edited by Roger Fulford and the sixth by Agatha Ramm. Christopher Hibbert's Queen Victoria in her Letters and Journals features selected letters between QV and some of her other children.

Although she was close to some of her grandchildren, QV remarked in a letter to her eldest daughter: I take interest in [the offspring] of my children when there are two or three—and of people who are dear to me and whom I am fond of—but when they come at the rate of three a year it becomes a cause of mere anxiety for my own children and of no great interest. 228

Victoria travelled often, both for pleasure and as part of her royal duties. Her love of the country and of domestic retreat led her to spend much of the winter at Windsor Castle or on the Isle of Wight, and most summers in Scotland. 836

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV travelled to Scotland with her young family for the first time.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She journeyed by sea, and quickly fell in love with the rugged Scottish coastline.
14-23

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV made a landmark visit to Louis-Philippe at Chateau d'Eu near Treport.

SHORTPROSE.P: This was the first time QV journeyed to foreign soil, and also the first time an English sovereign had visited a French sovereign since 1520.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The royal family purchased Osborne House in the Isle of Wight; the island then became a popular holiday destination for the upper classes.
QV and her family bought Balmoral Castle in the Scottish Highlands.
QV and her family made their initial visit to Ireland.
QV and Prince Albert's state visit to Louis-Napoleon and Eugénie was the first visit to Paris by an English monarch since 1431.

SHORTPROSE.P: QV's public appearances made her personally loved by many of her subjects, but also vulnerable. She exhibited considerable personal courage in her response to threats and assassination attempts.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: An assassination attempt was made on QV, pregnant with her first child, as she and Albert drove in an open carriage.

SHORTPROSE.P: The would-be assassin was a youth of eighteen named Edward Oxford. He was declared insane and committed to an asylum.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV was frightened to discover a young boy in her private dressing-room.

SHORTPROSE.P: Boy Jones, as he became known, had apparently visited the palace before, and returned after a sentence in prison. He was finally transported. 155

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A second assassination attempt on QV was made as she rode in her carriage; the man's pistol misfired.

SHORTPROSE.P: The potential assassin was a twenty year-old cabinet maker by the name of John Francis who was found to be not the least bit mad—but very cunning. 70 In a letter to King Leopold, QV describes the unfolding of events and comments that she and Prince Albert were both very glad that our drive had had the effect of having the man seized. Whether [the pistol] was loaded or not we cannot yet tell, but we are again full of gratitude to Providence for invariably protecting us! The feeling of horror is very great in the public, and great affection is shown us . . . Everything is to be kept secret at this time, which is very right, and altogether I think it is being well done . . . I was really not at all frightened. 70
John Francis was condemned to death, a punishment with which the Queen agreed heartily; however, he was reprieved on July 1.

Only three days after Francis' assassination attempt, a man described by editor Christopher Hibbert as a deformed youth no more than four feet tall 70 with a pistol containing more tobacco than gunpowder attempted to finish the job.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A third assassination attempt was made on QV.

SHORTPROSE.P: The attack this time came from a John William Bean.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A fourth assassination attempt on QV was made by an Irishman using a homemade gun.

SHORTPROSE.P: William Hamilton was sentenced to seven years transportation. 81

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A fifth attempt to assassinate QV was made by an ex-lieutenant of the 10th Hussars.

SHORTPROSE.P: Robert Pate struck the Queen over the head with a cane after she left Cambridge House in Piccadilly . In a letter to King Leopold, Victoria wrote, I have not suffered except from my head, which is still very tender, the blow having been extremely violent, and the brass end of the stick fell on my head so as to make a considerable noise. 80 She felt the attack to be disgraceful and very inconceivable, and complained that it makes me nervous out driving, and I stare at any person coming near the carriage. 80 In her journal, she developed her feelings about this attack. Certainly it is very hard and very horrid, that I, a woman—a defenceless young woman should be exposed to insults of this kind, and be unable to go out quietly for a drive . . . for a man to strike any woman is most brutal, and I, as well as everyone else, think this far worse than any attempt to shoot, which, wicked as it is, is at least more comprehensible and more courageous. 80-1 Pate was not found insane, and was sentenced to seven years transportation. 80 192-3

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV was warned that Fenians were plotting to seize and possibly assassinate her.

SHORTPROSE.P: On being shown a telegram containing the threat, the Queen merely remarked: [t]oo foolish! 200

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A young man with Fenian connections was apprehended for an assassination attempt on QV; his pistol proved not to be loaded.

SHORTPROSE.P: While the Queen and her entourage were on a drive, QV's close personal servant and friend John Brown spotted the pistol in the hand of a bystander and wrestled the potential assassin to the ground. In her journal, Victoria wrote: [i]t is to good Brown and to his wonderful presence of mind that I greatly owe my safety, for he alone saw the boy rush round and followed him! 227 The Queen later learned that Arthur O'Connor's attempt was made in connection with the holding of Fenian prisoners whose release he hoped to secure. 390

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: A seventh attempt was made to assassinate QV.

SHORTPROSE.P: The potential assassin this time was Roderick McLean, who, after firing a pistol at the Queen and missing, was at once beaten by nearby Eton boys. Of this attack, Victoria wrote in her journal that she was really not shaken or frightened. 272

A keen reader, theatre-goer, and ballet and opera enthusiast throughout her life, QV had a passion for the literary, dramatic, and musical arts from an early age. Her love of visual art was also apparent, and she filled many sketchbooks with her drawings and watercolours, selections of which were eventually published. It is not surprising, then, that the Queen was a faithful supporter of creative endeavours and did much to foster cultural production in Britain during her reign. 31-2, 43

Among her favourite writers were Alfred Tennyson, Sir Walter Scott, George Eliot (whose The Mill on the Floss made a deep impression 116 on her), and Charles Kingsley, whose Two Years Ago QV found brimming with such truths, so much imagination, and a power of description and beauty of language which equals Walter Scott. 210 43 67 20 70-3 QV was also highly impressed with Aurora Leigh, by Elizabeth Barrett Browning, which she found to be very strange, very original full of talent and of some beautiful things—but at times dreadfully coarse—though very moral in its tendency—but an incredible book for a lady to have written. 188 Additionally, as an enthusiast for all things Scottish, the Queen was so fond of Burns's poems, calling them so poetical—so simple in their dear Scotch tongue, which is so full of poetry. 188 She also enjoyed Mary Elizabeth Braddon's sensationalist novel Lady Audley's Secret and Edward Bulwer-Lytton's Eugene Aram, although of the latter she remarked that beautifully written and fearfully interesting as it is, I am glad I have finished it, for I never feel quite at ease or at home when I am reading a Novel. 39 326 She was primarily a fan of history, poetry, sensation fiction, and romance; indeed, she complained that Anthony Trollope's Barchester Towers did not have enough romance in it. The people I could not interest myself in. 109

As to the drama, QV thought the works of William Shakespeare to be very coarse. 111 She recommended Faust and French plays, about which she said that [o]ne's dislike to a nation need not prevent one's admiring and being amused by what is good, clever, and amusing in it. 111

Beyond her own activities, which included correspondence with several writers, especially Alfred Tennyson, QV was a devoted patron of the arts who not only fostered their development but also envisioned them as having a moral role in society. She saw theatre as a means for social betterment, arguing that the lower classes should have access to drama, for I think the absence of innocent amusement for the poor people [is] a misfortune and an encouragement of vice. 112

As a powerful female leader, a long-reigning sovereign, an avid reader, and a published writer, QV inspired many writers to compose works either about her or in her honour. In addition, as Gail Turley Houston argues in Royalties: The Queen and Victorian Writers, the Queen was a crucial figure in the nexus of debate surrounding who was the proper representative of authority and who was the appropriate subject of representation. 51 Debates over British subjectivity, gender, and the powers of discourse often had recourse to QV, making her an important cultural icon not only for who she was, but also for the way her image circulated.

Charles Dickens, while recognizing the value that appeal to the crown could have for an author's socio-economic position and prestige, also felt that his power to create representations which would reflect and shape the Victorian age were, in a way, more significant than those powers held by the Queen. In a letter to Basil Hall on 28 January 1841, Dickens implied that his calling was above that of the Queen, for whom he had little time; he claimed that he was so intent on his writing that even if the Queen were to send for me . . . I wouldn't go to her. 88

Indeed, Dickens constructed the figure of QV as the converse of his own. Referred to as a feminine writer by literary critics, he sought to assert his masculinity and virility by representing the Queen as domestic and feminine, downplaying her influence and heightening his own. His anxiety about the role of the male writer compared to that of the female monarch was evident in many of his letters and actions. He masked his ambivalence with aloofness, repeatedly declining the Queen's invitations to meet with or to perform for her. Finally, after twenty-two years of requests, Dickens consented to meet with QV. At this audience he ranted about class issues, though he accepted the Queen's gift of her book More Leaves from the Journal of Our Life in the Highlands, which she had inscribed: From the humblest of authors to one of the greatest. 93 Yet her gift may not have been as humble as might appear: she was well aware of the popularity of her book, and her act of giving it to Dickens can be read as a reassertion of her representational powers and a sign of the still unresolved, unofficial competition between the two. 87-93

Sarah Stickney Ellis deployed the image of the Queen to fuse together notions of queenly womanhood (as a virtue for the average woman to strive for) with that of the female sovereign. In The Women of England, this popular conduct writer warned that with the British throne being now graced by a female sovereign it was surely not a time for the female part of the community to fall away from the high standard of moral excellence, to which they have been accustomed to look, in the formation of their domestic habits. 33

Elizabeth Barrett Browning is one of the best known authors whose works address, explicitly and implicitly, QV and the figure of a female monarch. Eventually deemed The Queen of Poetry herself, Barrett Browning used her writings to define her literary credo and form her own poetic, sovereign persona in contradistinction to and parallel with the female monarch's profession. 116 In her epic poem Aurora Leigh and her occasional pieces about QV at her accession (Victoria's Tears and The Young Queen) and her marriage to Prince Albert (Crowned and Wedded), Barrett Browning honoured Victoria and simultaneously implied that earthly rule was more mundane, and ultimately less important, than the poet's power to represent. 117

Most Victorian women writers commented in some way on the Queen's role. Christina Rossetti engaged with it positively in Our Widowed Queen, while George Eliot's narrator in Felix Holt, the Radical refers to Victoria as a little humbug of a queen. 79 78-9

Perhaps the author whose writings and politics addressed the Queen the most frequently was Margaret Oliphant, whose biographical works often championed female monarchs, especially Victoria. A critic, correspondent, even friend of QV, Oliphant strove to raise the status of women's work by addressing the feminization of labour in the nineteenth century and blurring the conventional Victorian distinctions between the public and private spheres. As Gail Turley Houston argues, she subtly directed attention to women's powers of representation, both as authors who create representations and leaders who represent the populace. 139-40

Tennyson had a closer personal relationship than any other writer with the Queen. QV and her court appointed him Poet Laureate on 19 November 1850. Following Prince Albert's death and the Queen's deepened appreciation of Tennyson's work, the two became friends and close correspondents. She wrote in her diary on 5 January 1862 that only those who have suffered as I do, can understand these beautiful poems. 67 At this time Victoria invited the poet to come to see her. At the visit, on 14 April 1862, Tennyson read from works including In Memoriam, and it seems that both poet and queen were a good deal moved. 69 Their relationship deepened even further after the death of John Brown. 21-30, 87

In her Passing of the Great Queen, Marie Corelli, like Sarah Stickney Ellis, linked QV's femininity to that of the women of Britain, but Corelli transforms her praise of Victoria's womanly virtue into an argument for the superiority of women's rule. Her portrayal of QV and Victorian womanhood can be read as empowering rather than as policing for women. 33-5, 77-8

Even more empowering was the way that Victorian suffragists deployed QV's image. In their writings, for instance in a newspaper article entitled The Franchise for Women, these feminists pointed out that while the highest political prerogative and dignity in this land is held by a woman and no law can be enacted without her concurrence, no writ issued but in her name, the vast majority of women do not belong to the body politic, but remain a non-political element side by side with the male population. 35 Ironically, QV's active opposition to women's rights, and her declaration in 1870 that she was most anxious to enlist every one who can speak or write to join in checking this mad, wicked folly of 'Woman's Rights', with all its attendant horrors, on which her poor feeble sex is bent, 34 became in itself one of a frequently-cited argument in favour of the female franchise. 33-4

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Prince Albert, consort of QV, died of typhoid in the Blue Room at Windsor Castle.

SHORTPROSE.P: The death of her husband devastated the queen. He had shown deep affection and commitment to his wife and children, and the images of happy nuclear family life circulating about the royal family were an accurate as well as a deliberate self-representation. While not attempting to dominate the queen, he took a close interest in the affairs of the state and often acted as her advisor and confidant. 33

After the death of her husband, QV's deep sorrow caused her to withdraw from public life for several years. She continued to dress in black clothes of mourning long after she became a widow. 58-9, 130-1 For half a decade, she remained in her country dwellings and never came to London, inciting even loyal monarchists to voice their discontent. Some of her subjects, who viewed her extended grief as appropriate for a widow but not for a leader, complained that her withdrawal was proof that a woman was unsuitable as a monarch. 55-6

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV made her first public appearance after Prince Albert's death. 58-9

SHORTPROSE.P: She drove out in an open carriage, and this, along with other later public appearances, helped to dispel rumours about her health and sanity which circulated during her seclusion. 58-9

These were soon displaced by salacious speculation based on the intimacy of the queen with her personal servant, John Brown, who became a significant source of emotional support in her widowhood. 59-60

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV began to entertain a psychic, Robert James Lees.

SHORTPROSE.P: He attracted her attention when he contacted Albert in the world beyond, and transmitted a message which included Albert's secret pet-name. 334

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: John Brown became personal servant to the widowed QV at Windsor, in addition to his position at Balmoral; this fuelled speculation about the queen's domestic purity.

SHORTPROSE.P: John Brown, a Highlander, had first entered the service of the royal family in 1851; Victoria's biographer Elizabeth Longford says she first mentioned him in her journal on 11 September 1849. After Prince Albert's death, QV became increasingly close to John Brown, and soon began to quote him to others. The ODNB observes that, paradoxically, Brown's membership of the lower classes made it possible for him to speak informally and brusquely to Victoria in a way that would have been unthinkable from somebody of higher rank.

In 1876 QV gave him his own cottage at Balmoral, despite the fact that he was not married. In response to this attention, newspapers began to make humorous references to her as Mrs Brown. 323, 325, 327 There is no evidence that the queen and John Brown had sexual relations, and the fact that Victoria thought of making public her memoir of him strongly suggests that they did not. But the existence of an intimate relationship suspected of being sexual posed a serious challenge to conventional proprieties. 61

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV learned that her ministers wished to exclude her Scots servant John Brown from her life, in an effort to rouse her to her public duty.

SHORTPROSE.P: The ministers were not only motivated by desire to have her return to an active public role, but were also responding to public and familial disapproval of the queen's relations with a man of the servant class, her social inferior. 63 Victoria was furious at the suggestion and refused to comply. 329-30

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: John Brown, personal servant to QV, was accorded the now middle-class title of Esquire and given a salary increase to £400 annually.
John Brown, QV's loyal servant and close friend, died at Windsor Castle, after thirty-four years in her service.

SHORTPROSE.P: The queen was grief-stricken at his death. Her devastation resembled that which she had experienced after the death of Prince Albert. In a letter to her secretary, Sir Henry Ponsonby, she compared the situation to the shock of 1861 when every link has been shaken and torn and at every turn and every moment the loss . . . is most cruelly missed. 67

Unlike the funerals of other royal servants, John Brown's was a lavish affair, complete with a card on the coffin from the queen, which read, in her own handwriting: A tribute of loving, grateful, and everlasting friendship and affection from his truest, best, and most faithful friend, Victoria R & I. 69 To his relatives, she wrote: Weep with me for we have lost the best, the truest heart that ever beat. 69 He was further memorialized with a granite headstone featuring lines commissioned from Tennyson, a life-sized statue by sculptor Edgar Boehm, plaster casts of his bust, and gold brooches and tie-pins bearing his image and the queen's monogram. 69-70

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV began to employ two Indian servants.

SHORTPROSE.P: One of them, Abdul Karim, was then a slim twenty-four year-old. He eventually became quite close to the queen, although her feelings for him never compared to those she had felt for the late John Brown.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Abdul Karim, QV's personal servant, was accorded the title of Munshi for his dedication to her service.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: Adrienne Munich gives the date as 1888. xix

SHORTPROSE.P: He was accorded this title because he claimed he did not come from the servant class.

Munshi means teacher in Hindustani and Urdu, and QV studied Hindustani with him to the point that she was able to speak a little to Indian soldiers who attended the celebration of the Diamond Jubilee.

Once the Munshi was raised to this level, QV had to struggle against courtiers who objected to his inclusion in activities of the royal household, to the point of refusing to acknowledge him. Their racism and class prejudice were buttressed by suspicions that he might be leaking confidential documents she had shown to him. She certainly came to feel from her association with him considerable sympathy for Muslims; she told her lady-in-waiting Lady Lytton that she wished the Mahommedans could be let alone by Missionaries. 38 38-9, 42
In 1892 Abdul Karim was further honoured with the title of Munshi Hafiz, and two years after that Victoria made him a Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire. xx

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV opened Parliament for the first time since Prince Albert's death nearly five years before.

SHORTPROSE.P: She continued to participate sparingly in public ceremony for the next decade.

After Benjamin Disraeli first became Prime Minister, somewhat briefly, on 27 April 1866, Victoria encountered a type of politician which was new to her. Prince Albert had distrusted Disraeli and favoured Gladstone; Victoria found Disraeli able, unusual, and full of poetry, romance and chivalry.
Whereas Gladstone lectured her, Disraeli consulted her.

Disraeli's return to office in February 1874 initiated a fruitful working relationship. Victoria had found Gladstone's Liberal agenda in many ways too innovative, and in the later years of her reign her sympathies lay instinctively with the Tories.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV was proclaimed Empress of India at Delhi, Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay.

SHORTPROSE.P: The title, which she initiated herself, reflected her self-image as the head of a massive empire rather than simply a nation; she believed in the imperial mission to protect the poor natives and advance civilization. 836

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The Empire celebrated QV's Golden Jubilee.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Jubilee was a time for lavish displays of loyalty, and featured a huge parade in which the Queen was the star attraction. As scholar Dorothy Thompson argues, it was a celebration aimed at holding together the complex and often competing strands that made up the empire, the country and the metropolis. 133 The festivities were designed to promote a feeling of unity and mass allegiance, and were marked by a wealth of biographies and poems celebrating QV's life, rule, and the image of the empire she embodied. 130-6 The Illustrated London News called the opening the grandest State ceremony of this generation; one, indeed, practically unique in the annals of modern England. 76

The notion of empire is always already intertwined with mercantilism. Critic Thomas Richards argues that the Jubilee was a crucial moment in the history of the commodity, when the charisma the Queen was yoked to material objects to create kitsch. 75-6 Her image was splashed across numerous products from flags to dishes, handkerchiefs to chocolates, and even mustard to condensed milk. QV's subjects could now display their loyalty through the act of commodity consumption. 130-2 More than ever before, they could figuratively bring the Queen into their homes. It is argued that this twinning of allegiance and mass consumerism was a new concept, and the public was both fascinated and awed by the spectacle it created. For this Jubilee, twenty-six thousand children were gathered in Hyde Park and entertained with games, amusements, food, and the gift of a souvenir mug for each. Inciting loyalty in the young was considered especially important, as a small—and emphatically gendered—rhyme by Rev Hardwicke Rawnsley illustrates: Little children grow to men; / Loyal now is loyal then. 131

Not all of QV's subjects were pleased with the idea of the Jubilee, however. Some were sceptical of the uncritical commercialization which played such a large role in the festivities. In Mary Elizabeth Braddon's unpublished fictional version of the Golden Jubilee, The Good Hermione, the generally cheerful narrator laments that everyone came forward with their particular fads, & everyone wanted his or her little adventure to profit by the queen's Jubilee. . . . everyone of all shades & denominations, clamoured for institutions, or halls, or museums, or almshouses, or schools, or creches, or recreation rooms, or libraries, to be built out of Jubilee money and endowed with Jubilee money. 58-9 Some liberals and socialists also feared the unbridled feelings of imperialism and nationalism the event fostered. One Vanity Fair writer viewed QV's reign as shameful, arguing [a]lthough in these fifty years we have waged only one European war (and that a war of collusion, when we were agreed with our enemy rather than our ally) we have waged a great number of wars in Africa and Asia; wars for the most part unjust, waged without due cause, and without Declaration of War. 135-6

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV laid the foundation-stone of the Imperial Institute, which was erected in honour of her fifty years' reign.

SHORTPROSE.P: This Renaissance-palatial building in South Kensington was intended to showcase modern developments in industry, agriculture, and communications.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The Empire celebrated QV's Diamond Jubilee, honouring her sixty years' rule.

SHORTPROSE.P: Like the Golden Jubilee ten years before, the celebration brimmed with a mixture of loyalty, fanfare, and consumer nationalism. 130-6

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV's eyesight began to fail because of cataracts; reading became very difficult for her, and even letter-writing was a problem.

SHORTPROSE.P: QV was already reliant upon a cane for walking, and often used a wheelchair because of her rheumatism. 421

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV's memory began to fail, and within a couple of months her general health seriously declined.
After entertaining guests in her home, QV collapsed.
The public was shocked by the official announcement that QV was close to death; most of her subjects could not imagine the Empire without her.

SHORTPROSE.P: She continued to perform official duties, although medical attendants believed her death to be imminent.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV died peacefully of old age at Osborne House.

SHORTPROSE.P: QV's funeral was attended by large crowds as her body was conveyed with military honours from Osborne through London to Windsor. 123

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: QV was laid in her final resting place at Frogmore, where her body joined that of her husband.

SHORTPROSE.P: She left her family one of the richest in Europe, although the estate she herself inherited had been seriously hampered by her father's debts. xiv
